I thought about the portal physics for a while after this video, particularly the "collision" part, and came to the conclusion that for physics to make sense, the portals should be considered one object, aka. two ENDS of one portal, not two SEPARATE portals. Moreover, this portal should be considered infinitely rigid, meaning, that if one end of the portal moves, the other one moves the exact same way, aka. doesn't move relative to the other end. Ideally, the portal should just be connecting two coordinates in space-time, thus impossible to be moved, but that's too boring as a portal created on earth would just stay behind, while the earth/solar system/galaxy/cluster moves away.

This solves our problems in a satisfying and understandable way:
• A portal collision never happens, like two ends of a hole cannot be pushed through eachother.
• Two ends move simultaneously, thus not creating any paradoxes concerning relative speeds (if you're able to move two ends separately, then would your speed be relative to a moving train with one end, when you're standing next to the stationary other?)
• A portal moving to the object doesn't give it any speed, as the relative speed never changes because the other end is moving the exact same way
• A piston pushing against itself simply pushes against itself without any movement, just like a person pushing their hands together.

However, this creates one terrifying possibility. We can only affix one portal end at a time to a physical object. Meaning, while one end of a portal is moving on a train, the other one is flying across space, cutting through every solid object, possibly even breaking down prime particles, as a portal's edge has zero thickness.

Forcing the portals to all be in one reference frame doesn't just simplify things in the case of classical paradoxes but also avoids relativistic paradoxes like time-travel. If all wormholes are in the same reference frame, you can only "time travel" relative to specific fast moving reference frames that presumably no one is actually in.
